title: Spur Martha Thomas excels and Miedema boosts Arsenal â€“ Full Time with Jessy Parker Humphreys
body_text:
Welcome to Full Time, The Athleticâ€™s womenâ€™s football column â€” a one-stop shop every Monday to discuss the big issues in the game in the UK and Europe.
The main story
As Tottenham Hotspur striker Martha Thomas bore down on the Aston Villa goal in the 72nd minute, the significance of what she was about to do might not have necessarily occurred to her.
Advertisement
When she curled in her third goal of the match, Thomas was not only completing a hat-trick to put Spurs 4-1 up, but she was also surpassing her Womenâ€™s Super League best for goals scored in a season. She now has six goals in four games this campaign â€” beating her previous record of five, with Manchester United in 2021-22 â€” and is top of the WSL goalscoring charts ahead of Brighton & Hove Albionâ€™s Elisabeth Terland (four) and Manchester Cityâ€™s Jill Roord, Katie McCabe of Arsenal and former United team-mate Rachel Williams (all three).
The 27-year-old Scotland international joined Spurs from Manchester United at the end of the transfer window. With England international Bethany England set to be out for some time as she recovers from a hip operation, eyebrows were raised when Polish forward Nikola Karczewska went on loan to Bayern Leverkusen and was replaced by the incoming Thomas. She had played just 408 WSL minutes last season for United, mostly from out wide.
However, Thomas has been essential to Spursâ€™ bright start, scoring in each of their four league matches and helping them reach 50 per cent of their points total from last season already. The 4-2 win over Villa was their first over a top-half WSL team since they beat Manchester City on September 12, 2021.
When asked about her brilliant run of form, Thomas praised her Spurs coach, Robert Vilahamn. â€œItâ€™s probably playing under someone that I know believes in me,â€ she said. â€œThatâ€™s important, thatâ€™s when I play my best football. Playing in my actual position.â€
â€œIf you give a good player the trust and self-confidence, you can see what sheâ€™s really made of,â€ Vilahamn said after the game. â€œThose national-team players on the bench at the biggest clubs, sometimes you can find that in them if you give them the trust.â€
Spurs recruited judiciously over the summer, with under-the-radar signings such as Finnish midfielder Olga Ahtinen and Swiss centre-back Luana Buhler excelling. Grace Clinton, the 20-year-old midfielder on loan from Manchester United, was rewarded for her form with a first senior England call-up last week. Vilahamnâ€™s side look well-organised, with wins against Villa, Brighton and Bristol City building on a positive opening-day display against Chelsea, even in defeat.
As the battle to reach the top of the WSL increases and more clubs look to plough investment into their womenâ€™s teams, Spursâ€™ early season impression should be a lesson. Star names can provide an instant uplift on and off the pitch (Tottenham know that better than anyone â€” signing England in January was crucial in keeping Spurs away from the relegation zone) but sometimes you donâ€™t have to splash the cash to build something good. And right now, England herself might be wondering where she stands when she returns to full fitness.
Advertisement
What you might have missed
Normally you expect to see WSL players streaming off a coach or arriving in their cars before a match, but not so for Chelsea midfielder Sjoeke Nusken. The 22-year-old Germany international arrived by bike at Kingsmeadow before her second start for the club, and her performance impressed just as much as her environmental credentials.
Sjoeke Nusken really turned up to Kingsmeadow on a bike and bagged a perfect hat-trick against Brighton. ğŸ¤£ğŸš² pic.twitter.com/xyGRYR9tjd
â€” London Is Blue Podcast â­ï¸â­ï¸ (@LondonBluePod) October 22, 2023
Having gone a goal down to Brighton, Nusken equalised for Chelsea on the stroke of half-time. She scored again just after the break before laying on an assist for Agnes Beever-Jones, paving the way for Chelseaâ€™s 4-2 win. All of that came as a surprise to a player many assumed the WSL champions had signed to be a defensive midfielder.
â€œI play every position in the midfield,â€ Nusken said after the match, â€œso sometimes in the â€™10â€™ or in the pivot.â€
Manager Emma Hayes concurred: â€œShe wants and likes to go forward, somewhere between the No 8 and the No 10. But sheâ€™s front-footed, really aggressive and sheâ€™ll get in the box.â€
The only sour note was that Nusken was denied a perfect hat-trick â€” her scrambled effort in the 74th minute went down as an own goal for Guro Bergsvand. â€œI touched the ball,â€ Nusken insisted, and cycled defiantly back home with her match ball in tow.
Player of the week
Leicester City vs Manchester City was the unusual table-topping clash and the away side were forced to work hard for their 1-0 win, ending the hostâ€™s unbeaten start to the season. Leicester stayed in the game thanks to the tireless work of defender Sophie Howard, and were probably unlucky not to score themselves. Playing in the middle of a back three, Howard was given the unenviable task of marking Bunny Shaw â€” Cityâ€™s top scorer from last season (31 across all competitions).
Howard was dragged out of position in the first half but rallied in the second to frustrate Shaw. Her efforts were ultimately in vain but the Scotland internationalâ€™s dogged defending was an example of how well-organised manager Willie Kirk has made this side.
Advertisement
Moment of the week
Arsenal striker Vivianne Miedema finally made her return to WSL action this weekend, 11 months after suffering an anterior cruciate ligament rupture in a Champions League game against Lyon. The Netherlands international, who was selected last week for their Nations League fixtures against Scotland on Friday and next Tuesday, was a late substitute in her sideâ€™s win against Bristol City.
GO DEEPER
The real and emotional impact of ACL injuries on female elite players
With striker Beth Mead returning to play last week, manager Jonas Eidevallâ€™s attacking options are now complete. â€œItâ€™s such a joyful moment,â€ said Eidevall post-match. â€œI am very happy for players that have been out for a long time, working so hard and now being able to come back to us on the pitch.
â€œTo have them both back within a week of each other is so special for the team,â€ said Republic of Ireland captain Katie McCabe.
Out of the remaining ACL injuries list, only defenders are left â€” England captain Leah Williamson and Austria international Laura Wienroither.
Whatâ€™s happening next?
The domestic club season will be paused as the international game takes over, with Nations League fixtures and Olympic qualification the focus for many. England face Belgium in home and away matches on Friday and next Tuesday.
The Ballon dâ€™Or winner will be announced on October 30. Spainâ€™s Alexia Putellas will almost certainly be relinquishing her hold on the trophy after winning the last two years in a row. Barcelona midfielder Aitana Bonmati, who won the World Cup with Spain, is the favourite to win this yearâ€™s edition.
The WSL action starts again on November 4. The following day, Arsenal and Manchester City go head to head for the first time this season.
